title: Robb my countries treasures
content:
Hi Typophilers,   
   
I would be interested in design stuff that's made in your town, whereever you are outthere in the world.   
I'm living in Maastricht (Holland) and Düsseldorf (Germany) and we have some interesting stuff going on in graphic design. We could exchange flyers, brochures, photo's, typothings, and so on, if you would be interested. In that way you get to know what we do here, and I what you do over there. It doesn't have to be made by you. You could robb the local flyer display and anything you find on the streets and send that. I like more to have printed work than to see that on an internet site. The paper adds another dimension to the work.   
   
Are there people who would be interested in something like that?   
I find that living out here can very fast become limited if you don't open your eyes and start to look around. In the old days people travelled all over the world and robbed countries of there national treasures to enhance there own. We could do the same on a friendly base.   
   
If you would be interested, please reply, and we could get exchanging neat stuff.   
I can't send the same stuff to everyone (mail is expensive) but a lot is possible.   
   
Regards,   
Ren�

But Ren�, won't it be a better idea to just scan them in so that more people can see them?   
   
If more people take part, won't you end up like sending out 10 sets of everything?

You'd lose the texture in a scan...   
If this really takes of, we could make a rotational system or something.   
Besides, wouldn't you love to get a nice fat letter full of foreign design every once in a while?   
I'd love getting something from Singapore.   
Come on, it'll be fun!

You could set it up this way. The first person, e.g. Yves, sends three pieces of stuff to two other people to get the ball rolling. Each of these people send three pieces back to the first person, and send three pieces on to other people. Each recipient sends three things back to the person who sent to them, and three things on to other people.

I think John's got quite a good system there. For a start at least. I'll start collecting stuff right now.   
   
I always collect stuff when I travel, but back home, I kinda just take everything for granted.   
   
Should we come up with a criteria for the items collected? Eg: Does it need to be designed locally?   
   
More later then.
